Name: Ensure that participants in the Special Supplemental Nutrition Program for Women, Infants and Children may receive foods from any vendor approved by such program, including infant formula.  (S.7049/A.9648)
Title: Resolution calling upon the New York State Legislature to pass and Governor Cuomo to sign S.7049/A.9648, which would ensure that participants in the Special Supplemental Nutrition Program for Women, Infants and Children may receive foods from any vendor approved by such program, including infant formula

History.Description: This Resolution was Introduced by Council
This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Health
This Resolution was Filed (End of Session)

Attachments.Name: April 20, 2016 - Stated Meeting Agenda with Links to Files

Text:
By Council Members Espinal and Mealy
      Whereas, Special Supplemental Nutrition Program for Women, Infants and Children ("WIC") is a federal nutrition program that supports eligible low-income pregnant, postpartum, and breastfeeding women, infants and children up to the age of five, and promotes better health for these families; and
      Whereas, WIC provides nutrition education and counseling, breastfeeding support, prenatal and postpartum support, referrals and supplemental food vouchers; and
      Whereas, Foods that are WIC approved include low or fat free milk, fruits and vegetables, whole grains, infant formula, and other essential items; and
      Whereas, According to the New York State Department of Health ("DOH") website, "WIC vendors are grocery stores and pharmacies who are authorized to issue healthy supplemental foods to WIC participants in exchange for WIC food instruments (WIC checks) and vouchers"; and 
      Whereas, In  February 2014, DOH implemented a policy change which only allows WIC vendors that are pharmacies or stores with a pharmacy department to redeem WIC checks for infant formulas issued with a prescription, known as exempt or specialty formulas; and
      Whereas, According to an article in Crain's New York Business, the new policy was created in response to fraudulent activity where store owners were providing cash instead of infant formula, for example, in exchange for WIC vouchers; and
      Whereas, As a result, the State retroactively eliminated all stores without a pharmacy from selling specialty infant formula, thus, limiting the ability of WIC participants to access such products in their local neighborhoods; and
      Whereas, Many WIC recipients must travel long distances from their homes to buy formula, and may experience more financial hardship due to transportation costs; and
      Whereas, Limiting the number of WIC vendors that can accept WIC checks for exempt infant formula can have an adverse effect on a young child's health if a mother has difficulty finding a store that is conveniently located to meet her child's needs; and
      Whereas, S.7049, sponsored by State Senator Klein, and A.9648, sponsored by Assembly Member Crespo, would ensure that participants in the WIC program have access to all WIC approved products, including exempt or specialty infant formulas at any WIC approved vendor; now, therefore, be it
      Resolved, That the Council of the City of New York calls upon the New York State Legislature to pass and Governor Cuomo to sign S.7049/A.9648, which would ensure that participants in the Special Supplemental Nutrition Program for Women, Infants and Children may receive foods from any vendor approved by such program, including infant formula.

LS # 7671
3/30/2016
TC

\pard\ltrpar\sa200\sl276\slmult1\qj By Council Members Espinal and Mealy\par
\pard\ltrpar\fi720\sl480\slmult1\qj Whereas, Special Supplemental Nutrition Program for Women, Infants and Children (\ldblquote WIC\rdblquote )\cf1  \cf0 is a federal nutrition program that supports eligible low-income pregnant, postpartum, and breastfeeding women, infants and children up to the age of five, and promotes better health for these families; and\par
Whereas, WIC provides nutrition education and counseling, breastfeeding support, prenatal and postpartum support, referrals and supplemental food vouchers; and\par
Whereas, Foods that are WIC approved include low or fat free milk, fruits and vegetables, whole grains, infant formula, and other essential items; and\par
Whereas, According to the New York State Department of Health (\ldblquote DOH\rdblquote ) website, \ldblquote WIC vendors are grocery stores and pharmacies who are authorized to issue healthy supplemental foods to WIC participants in exchange for WIC food instruments (WIC checks) and vouchers\rdblquote ; and \par
Whereas, In  February 2014, DOH implemented a policy change which only allows WIC vendors that are pharmacies or stores with a pharmacy department to redeem WIC checks for infant formulas issued with a prescription, known as exempt or specialty formulas; and\par
Whereas, According to an article in \i Crain\rquote s New York Business\i0 , the new policy was created in response to fraudulent activity where store owners were providing cash instead of infant formula, for example, in exchange for WIC vouchers; and\par
Whereas, As a result, the State retroactively eliminated all stores without a pharmacy from selling specialty infant formula, thus, limiting the ability of WIC participants to access such products in their local neighborhoods; and\par
Whereas, Many WIC recipients must travel long distances from their homes to buy formula, and may experience more financial hardship due to transportation costs; and\par
Whereas, Limiting the number of WIC vendors that can accept WIC checks for exempt infant formula can have an adverse effect on a young child\rquote s health if a mother has difficulty finding a store that is conveniently located to meet her child\rquote s needs; and\par
Whereas, S.7049, sponsored by State Senator Klein, and A.9648, sponsored by Assembly Member Crespo, would ensure that participants in the WIC program have access to all WIC approved products, including exempt or specialty infant formulas at any WIC approved vendor; now, therefore, be it\par
Resolved, That the Council of the City of New York calls upon the New York State Legislature to pass and Governor Cuomo to sign S.7049/A.9648, which would ensure that participants in the Special Supplemental Nutrition Program for Women, Infants and Children may receive foods from any vendor approved by such program, including infant formula.\par
